name: Mith's Blood And Faith Cleric Build, modification thoughts?
author: Shinyasuo

posts.author: Shinyasuo
posts.content:
Hi Guys,

im not an expert of DnD Rules and such, I bought NWN EE on STeam, looked for a build for a cleric and found:
mith-s-blood-and-faith-cleric-26-bard-4 ... 15481.html

Now I wanted to ask how much I would cripple this build when using a light flail/warhammer/morningstar (one of these 3 is fine, im just a fan of blunt weapons) instead of the scimitar???

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello and welcome, Shinyasuo!

Using any of the three weapons you mention won't cripple the build, so don't worry.

The reason for taking scimitar is for critical hits. With a crit range of 15-20 (with the Improved Critical feat), you have a 30% chance of double damage with each hit. The three weapons you're looking at have a crit range of 19-20 (again with Imp Crit), which is a 10% chance. Just to complicate matters, though, if you do land a crit with a warhammer, you get triple damage rather than double. Also, with a morningstar, you land both bludgeoning and piercing damage (the other two are both "just" bludgeoning, while scimitar is "just" slashing). Morningstar is also a simple weapon, so you wouldn't need to take the Weapon Proficiency: Martial feat, giving you the option to take something else in its place, which is always nice.

The handy thing with bludgeoning damage is that it is less frequently resisted by enemies, and is particularly effective (generally) against those immune to crits, such as undead and constructs. Oh, and the three weapons you cite give you d8 damage (if I remember correctly), while the scimitar gives d6.

I suppose what I'm saying is that it's swings and roundabouts: use any weapon that makes you feel good! For myself, I'd go for the morningstar for the two types of damage and the free feat it offers.

Hope this helps.

Cheers

EDIT: Btw, if you do go for morningstar, I'd take Blind Fight at level 1 and replace it at level 18 with Lightning Reflexes, which will help with what Mith recognises as a weak Reflex save. But that's just me.

EDIT 2: Shall we assume you're the small one in your avatar pic? 😉

posts.content: I agree with Stag, except I would lean towards choosing the warhammer for the +3 crits, although the free feat from choosing morningstar is very tempting.

Great to hear from you Shinyasuo
And that is a classic build you have chosen, I think you have excellent taste, Mithdradates has number of very good builds.
In terms of the weapon the Grimnir/Empyre65/Stagmeister have answered that really well

If it is of interest I have been trying for a few months to find improvements (ie things to add to make it better) to this build which was written in 2006, about 14 years ago
One was trying to make it more balanced which Mithdradates actually alluded to in terms of the weaknesses he thought were present in the build
This is the last discussion the ECB Guild had regarding this

more-balanced-blood-and-faith-cleric-28 ... 55384.html

Sometimes small advancements can be made by standing on the shoulders of giants, as they say.

If you are new to NWN (am unsure if you are), in terms of the environment you will want to play this build somewhere where you get close to Level 40 to observe its full potential.

I can't remember the full list of single player modules but Aielund saga I-VI gets to level 36-38 which is pretty good, this is free at the NWN Vault

Others I hear about that are good are Mines of Twin Summit (to lvl 40), Sands of Fate (level 40)
Lord of Terror gets to 30 so grab that Bard1 /RDD 10 from level 21-29 
Bioware's Shadows of Undrentide and Hordes of the Underdark gets to 28 
Aribeth's Redemption looks like it gets to about 28 as well
Not sure about Swordflight I presume that goes quite high, but I hear it is quite difficult if you like that:)

Hope that helps

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Mines of Twin Summit is a great series of modules to follow the OC to go all the way to level 40.  It was designed for a party, so there are no henchmen, but a good build can go it alone.

SoU starts at level 1, and HotU is designed to follow it.  If you follow that with the Sands of Fate series, you will go all the way to level 40.  A fun option is to play The Nether Scrolls as a bridge module between SoU and HotU.

The deservedly-legendary Aielund Saga will take you from level 1 through level 36.  It is a must-play.

I have played these and most of the other ones Orion mentioned many times each, with different builds.  I recommend all of them,  with a variety of builds to it doesn't get repetitive.

I should add Swordflight to my to-play list, but I hear that the series is not finished, and I am concerned about being left hanging mid-story.  Can anybody who has played Swordflight say whether that is a valid reason to wait to play it?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
My understanding is that Swordflight is going to be a 6 or 7 part series, ending at level 40. Its author, Rogueknight, seems to be completing a module about every 12-18 months, so we may get part 5 sometime this year.

Aielund remains the best of the best for me, however. And certainly has the best narrative arc.

If you're interested, @Shinyasuo, have a look in our Modules forum, where there's plenty of discussion on all of these modules, as well as some other worthy ones.
